moves.1. e4 e6: The French Defense, which can lead to very cramped positions for Black if it is mishandled.
moves.2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. exd5: Spielmann immediately opens up the game. He loves to launch quick attacks.
moves.4... exd5 5. Bg5: Spielmann knows that the pin is mightier than the sword.
moves.5... Be7: Immediately countering. Black should now look to castle and move his Queen off of Q 1.
moves.6. Bd3 Nc6 7. Nge2 Nb4: A good move, threatening to remove White's crucial light-squared Bishop.
moves.8. Ng3 Nxd3+ 9. Qxd3: Black should now seek to clear his back rank and castle.
moves.9... g6: This catastrophic blunder irreparably wrecks Black's King-side.
moves.12... Qxe7: Forced, but now the Knight on K B 3 is pinned -- and because of 9... P - K Kt 3???, it must be protected by pieces. There is also a dangerous hole at K R 3.
moves.13. Qf3: Spielmann adds pressure to the pinned Knight.
moves.13... Kg7: Forced, to avoid losing the piece.
moves.14... dxe4 15. Nxe4: The pinned piece is now doomed, and the Black King-side in a state of collapse.
moves.15... Qe6: If Black tries 15... Q x Kt, Spielmann has 16 Q x Kt ch K - Kt 1 17 B - R 6 forcing mate.
moves.16. Bxf6+: The logical conclusion to the pinning attack.
moves.17. Qf4: Black resigns, as there is no defense against the coming 18 Q - R 6. The pin was the weapon that smashed the Black King-side.
